name: accordion
definition: A portable wind instrument with a small keyboard and free metal reeds that sound when air is forced past them by pleated bellows operated by the player.
description:
The accordion is a musical instrument that has keys similar to a piano, but is small enough for a person to hold. It was invented in the early 1800s by Friedrich Buschmann in Germany.

In German the instrument was referred to as the Akkordeon, a name derived from the word 'Akkord' which means 'musical chord, concord of sounds'.

Accordion has an expandable section named bellows, located in between keyboards and buttons. The bellows are made of cloth, cardboard, leather and metal.

The bellows are expanded and contracted by the accordionist, which creates vacuum and pressure, driving air through the reed chambers that creates the sound.

The accordion is used in pop music, folk music, cajun music, jazz, classical, zydeco and dance-pop.

The accordion has also been referred to affectionately as the squeezebox.

contextual.caption: The accordion is relatively large and requires a little bit of familiarity when holding it. An additional strap can be very useful. The back strap keeps the shoulder straps together so that the accordion doesn't move.

featured.caption: There is also a variant that uses buttons to play notes.

facts.name: The accordion is used in pop music.
facts.value: The accordion is used in pop music, folk music, cajun music, jazz, classical, zydeco, and dance-pop.

facts.name: On Carnegie Hall accordion was first played in 1939.
facts.value: The first to play the accordion in New York City's famous Carnegie Hall were Gene von Halberg, Abe Goldman, and Joe Biviano, in 1939.

facts.name: The 1900s to the 1960s is the 'Golden Age of the Accordion'.
facts.value: The 1900s to the 1960s has been referred to as the 'Golden Age of the Accordion'.

facts.name: In 1990 there were an estimated 75,000 accordionists in U.S.
facts.value: There were an estimated 75,000 people in the United States in 1990 that could be classified as accordionists.

facts.name: Right-hand manual accordions looks like a piano.
facts.value: Right-hand manual accordions can have a chromatic or diatonic button board, or a keyboard that looks like a piano.

facts.name: The accordion is able to sustain long sounds.
facts.value: The accordion is able to sustain sound for a much longer time than most other instruments.

facts.name: A bisonoric accordion is able to produce different pitches.
facts.value: A bisonoric accordion is able to produce different pitches. This is dependent on the direction the bellows are moved.

facts.name: Pietro Deiro is the 'Daddy of the Accordion'.
facts.value: Pietro Deiro, an Italy-born accordionist was known as the 'Daddy of the Accordion'. He had a career in San Francisco during the vaudeville era and was even signed to RCA Victor Records.

facts.name: A unisonoric accordion will produce the same pitch.
facts.value: A unisonoric accordion will produce the same pitch regardless of the direction the bellows are moved. Size also plays a factor in the pitch.

facts.name: Accordions are still made with a lot of human hands work.
facts.value: Accordions are still made with a lot of human hands as opposed to by machinery. Some parts are made by machine but the best are mostly hand made by craftsman.

facts.name: Weird Al Yankovic is a parodist that uses accordion.
facts.value: Weird Al Yankovic is a Grammy-winning parodist who incorporates polkas into his music with his accordion. He was trained as a child to play the instrument.
